componenttext: Got it. Appreciate that. And then, Tim, you had mentioned that, obviously, companies that are better capitalized are in a better position, especially in this volatile oil market that we're in. Can you guys give us your 10,000-foot view on M&A going forward here, considering what's occurred and how does Concho play into that?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, we're really focused on running our business efficiently. And I do think -- I mean, we've seen consolidations happen in our industry. I think individual deals are just that, they are individual deals if they are all different. So I don't think you c
componenttext: Well, we're really focused on running our business efficiently. And I do think -- I mean, we've seen consolidations happen in our industry. I think individual deals are just that, they are individual deals if they are all different. So I don't think you can characterize consolidation by any one deal or perhaps the last deal that just happened. But I do think the industry, in general, is going to have to get more efficient. And to get more efficient than these companies and the industries going to have to be better capitalized and be able to run at lower cost with less debt. And so I think we'll see that happen. I'm not sure how that affects Concho. Concho is really well positioned with the property base we have and where we're located. I think we can continue to do what we do for a very long time. So we've -- I think our #1 mission right now is just to continue to create a more efficient company with what we've got.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate that. But just out of curiosity, are you -- I'm assuming you guys look at the market constantly. Have you seen anything change in that market over the last several months?
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate that. But just out of curiosity, are you -- I'm assuming you guys look at the market constantly. Have you seen anything change in that market over the last several months?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the second quarter was maybe the worst quarter we've ever had as an industry as far as the oil price movement and just -- so yes, I think that everybody was looking at their business plan, and there were very few business plans that were via
componenttext: Well, I mean, the second quarter was maybe the worst quarter we've ever had as an industry as far as the oil price movement and just -- so yes, I think that everybody was looking at their business plan, and there were very few business plans that were viable in our industry. So I think that forces the industry to reevaluate itself.

componenttext: First, I guess my 2 questions is, well, based on, Tim, what you and Will said earlier. First, Will had mentioned -- talked about maintenance capital and other question, and then Tim, not a surprise, you talked about returning -- or just talked about shareholder returns. So both of my questions are on this, I'm just wondering on the -- I think it's $350 million to $375 million per quarter maintenance capital. My first question is, is that -- do you anticipate that continuing to come down even a bit more. It just seems like you guys are doing an incredible job with efficiencies, and then my second part today would be, if that does come down or, I guess, let's say, the adverse of that prices go up, it sounds like, Tim, would you just keep that the same and not grow production anymore and just take that capital and give it back to shareholders? Or I'm just wondering, again, basically around this maintenance capital. Can it get any better? And what would you do with the excess?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that and then let Tim or Jack take the second. I mean as it relates to what we've been able to do so far this year, I can't say enough positive things about our drilling and completion teams and what they have done to take adva
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that and then let Tim or Jack take the second. I mean as it relates to what we've been able to do so far this year, I can't say enough positive things about our drilling and completion teams and what they have done to take advantage of not only the lower service cost environment we're in and to have the flexible program and be able to take advantage of that. But also the efficiency gains, the cycle time, the footage per day improvement, et cetera, it's been really impressive. And I'm optimistic that given more time, the machine will continue to grind out gains. And over some measure of time, we will continue to deliver.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. Neal, I think the answer to your other question is, as I mentioned, at the very opening that we're going to be very cautious on increasing any kind of activity and require a much stronger and longer price signals from the market before we do such.
componenttext: Yes. Neal, I think the answer to your other question is, as I mentioned, at the very opening that we're going to be very cautious on increasing any kind of activity and require a much stronger and longer price signals from the market before we do such.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: So Tim, let me ask one last one. So does that mean you'd consider -- even though it is potentially would be called a variable dividend, is that something you would look at and something you'd consider from time to time throughout the year when you conside
componenttext: So Tim, let me ask one last one. So does that mean you'd consider -- even though it is potentially would be called a variable dividend, is that something you would look at and something you'd consider from time to time throughout the year when you consider shareholder return options?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not really ready to talk about the mechanic of it, but the concept of a variable dividends being talked about throughout our industry, and I think we'd be well positioned to do something like that.
componenttext: Yes. I'm not really ready to talk about the mechanic of it, but the concept of a variable dividends being talked about throughout our industry, and I think we'd be well positioned to do something like that.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with KeyBanc.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on free cash flow. It certainly seems like your message was pretty clear in terms of what you'd be doing in the second half of the year with, I guess, building cash to reduce net debt. But I guess, maybe just kind o
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on free cash flow. It certainly seems like your message was pretty clear in terms of what you'd be doing in the second half of the year with, I guess, building cash to reduce net debt. But I guess, maybe just kind of going forward into next year, I wanted to get a sense of how share buybacks might play into the equation here. Wasn't a word that I heard you guys, I guess, mention of late?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo, this is Jack. Yes, as Tim alluded to earlier, I think we can get substantially there on our debt reduction by the end of this year with perhaps a little bit of work to do next year. But beyond that, what we've described in the past and on this c
componenttext: Yes, Leo, this is Jack. Yes, as Tim alluded to earlier, I think we can get substantially there on our debt reduction by the end of this year with perhaps a little bit of work to do next year. But beyond that, what we've described in the past and on this call is a range of opportunities between increasing dividends, share buyback or further cash build. And I think we really have to see what the circumstances look like at that point in time to determine which one is the most effective.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess just -- I know it's kind of tough to say how things play out, obviously, on the oil price side as we get into next year. But we've kind of stabilized here at roughly $40, and it sounds like the situation you guys are describing is that y
componenttext: Okay. And I guess just -- I know it's kind of tough to say how things play out, obviously, on the oil price side as we get into next year. But we've kind of stabilized here at roughly $40, and it sounds like the situation you guys are describing is that you can kind of start to stabilize your oil volumes into year-end? I mean I don't want to put words in your mouth, but it would be reasonable to assume that if we continue to muddle along at $40 next year, we should think of Concho volumes as fairly flat and activity fairly flat. And you guys talk about needing a much higher oil price to potentially grow again? Would that be closer to 45%? Just trying to get some bookends as to how this can play out.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we came into this year, we described our business plan in the $50 environment and the things we could do. And as prices have bounced around and costs have changed, clearly, what could be done at $50 can now be done at a lower price. And when we
componenttext: Sure. When we came into this year, we described our business plan in the $50 environment and the things we could do. And as prices have bounced around and costs have changed, clearly, what could be done at $50 can now be done at a lower price. And when we look out at the strip currently and what we think our business can do, it's a viable business that can achieve a lot of the same objectives we came into the year talking about.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just lastly on the shut-ins. Are all those back online at this point? And any -- if not, can you quantify what's still off-line?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just lastly on the shut-ins. Are all those back online at this point? And any -- if not, can you quantify what's still off-line?

componenttext: It's all generally on.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Portillo with TPH.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Portillo with TPH.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Can you just briefly discuss, I guess, your thoughts around permitting on federal acreage? How much running room you have at the moment? And then as you mentioned in the prepared remarks, just the quality of the reservoir on federal acreage relative to no
componenttext: Can you just briefly discuss, I guess, your thoughts around permitting on federal acreage? How much running room you have at the moment? And then as you mentioned in the prepared remarks, just the quality of the reservoir on federal acreage relative to nonfederal acreage in New Mexico? And kind of how we should think about your inventory profile potentially allowing you to avoid drilling federal lands if there is a slowdown on permitting or other issues?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Matt, it's Will. That obviously is very topical right now. I think one of the challenges is, it's hard to know exactly what and how a new administration might do to limit onshore development. From a federal permitting front, though, we believe we have eno
componenttext: Matt, it's Will. That obviously is very topical right now. I think one of the challenges is, it's hard to know exactly what and how a new administration might do to limit onshore development. From a federal permitting front, though, we believe we have enough permits in hand that we're in process for probably 1 to 2 years' worth of drilling on our federal acreage. I think probably more importantly though, we've run a number of scenarios in an event we're unable to develop our federal acreage in New Mexico over the next 5 years. And we feel confident we can quickly shift our capital to other acreage in our portfolio without any significant impact to our capital efficiency over that period.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Great. And then a follow-up question for Tim. Just philosophically longer term, I was curious how you're thinking about capital allocation to the drill bit relative to cash flow. And specifically, if there's kind of a longer-term plan around reinvestment
componenttext: Great. And then a follow-up question for Tim. Just philosophically longer term, I was curious how you're thinking about capital allocation to the drill bit relative to cash flow. And specifically, if there's kind of a longer-term plan around reinvestment of that capital allocation potentially below your cash flow profile to continue to drive free cash flow generation through the cycles.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as I mentioned, I'm just happy to get through the second quarter in such good shape. As far as looking out long term, we just see being able to deliver more free cash flow with a lower reinvestment rate back into the business over a longer
componenttext: Well, I think, as I mentioned, I'm just happy to get through the second quarter in such good shape. As far as looking out long term, we just see being able to deliver more free cash flow with a lower reinvestment rate back into the business over a longer period of time. So I don't think we're prepared to talk about percentages or anything like that right now, but it just -- it looks good over a long period of time that how much free cash flow we can generate as a business.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng with Scotiabank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng with Scotiabank.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Tim, you said that the business needs to change to be more disciplined and also they are generating better free cash flow and better return. We totally agree. And from that standpoint, do you have a target that you can share for Concho? What's the longer-
componenttext: Tim, you said that the business needs to change to be more disciplined and also they are generating better free cash flow and better return. We totally agree. And from that standpoint, do you have a target that you can share for Concho? What's the longer-term asset cycle, the return on capital employed? And also that you will be targeting that you think will need to be in order to attract investors, competing with general market? And also that when I think that some of other companies that your peer that will be targeting, say, an overall investment, maybe 70% of the total cash flow on a full out cycle. Is that approach that you believe is reasonable for the industry and for yourself? And if not, why not?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Paul, it's Jack. Let me piece that out a little bit. I think on the first part of the question, our business needs to generate returns, and we need to generate returns that exceed our cost of capital. And we think we have a business that can do that. So t
componenttext: Paul, it's Jack. Let me piece that out a little bit. I think on the first part of the question, our business needs to generate returns, and we need to generate returns that exceed our cost of capital. And we think we have a business that can do that. So that's point number one. And I guess the second part of your question had to do with cash flow at percentages of reinvestment. And again, going back to some things that we've said on this call, we think we're positioning our business to allow for that type of flexibility to invest more efficiently and increase our free cash flow. So by definition, that would mean a lower percentage of our cash flow over time would be necessary to maintain or grow production.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Jack, in terms of the return on capital employed, obviously, you are one of the few who can do better than your cost of capital. But to compete with the market, how much better do you think you need to be in order to be competitive? I'm just trying to see
componenttext: Jack, in terms of the return on capital employed, obviously, you are one of the few who can do better than your cost of capital. But to compete with the market, how much better do you think you need to be in order to be competitive? I'm just trying to see that what is the expectation from the company. What will you be targeting?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm very competitive. So the more, the better. And I hope that you're seeing evidence of that in our -- in the actions we're taking, in our cost structure, our realizations for our oil and the efficiency on the drilling and completion side. So my ex
componenttext: Well, I'm very competitive. So the more, the better. And I hope that you're seeing evidence of that in our -- in the actions we're taking, in our cost structure, our realizations for our oil and the efficiency on the drilling and completion side. So my expectation is that we're going to maintain the intensity on all of those things.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: A final question for me. A very quick one. For the federal land, if I'm looking at, not from a total land position but from an inventory backlog standpoint, what is the federal land inventory as a percentage to your total inventory?
componenttext: A final question for me. A very quick one. For the federal land, if I'm looking at, not from a total land position but from an inventory backlog standpoint, what is the federal land inventory as a percentage to your total inventory?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. It's about -- the federal acreage is about 20% of our total net acreage. And so from an inventory standpoint, it's higher than that. I mean the federal acreage is generally good acreage, especially in Lake County. So it's something between pro
componenttext: Sure, Paul. It's about -- the federal acreage is about 20% of our total net acreage. And so from an inventory standpoint, it's higher than that. I mean the federal acreage is generally good acreage, especially in Lake County. So it's something between probably 25% and 30% of our total inventory.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, on the DCF, the wicked questions have been asked. So I appreciate you getting on. Let me try a couple of -- maybe just ask slightly differently on the sustaining capital. Ex-hedging, where would you say your oil breakeven is at this point on the $35
componenttext: Well, on the DCF, the wicked questions have been asked. So I appreciate you getting on. Let me try a couple of -- maybe just ask slightly differently on the sustaining capital. Ex-hedging, where would you say your oil breakeven is at this point on the $350 million per quarter.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Doug, it's Jack. Let me take a shot at that. I think that our breakeven to cover our program and our dividend is somewhere in the mid- to high 30s range on oil.
componenttext: Doug, it's Jack. Let me take a shot at that. I think that our breakeven to cover our program and our dividend is somewhere in the mid- to high 30s range on oil.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. Now I've obviously got to take a shot at the whole comments around the business model because I think, finally, the market might be waking up to how the value is established in these businesses, in your business, in particular, and in
componenttext:
Okay. That's great. Now I've obviously got to take a shot at the whole comments around the business model because I think, finally, the market might be waking up to how the value is established in these businesses, in your business, in particular, and in terms of discounted free cash flow. So all your comments, Tim, have been pressing and great to hear you reiterate all this morning. 
My question is this, if and when oil prices do recover, how do you think about a planning process going forward? I mean, obviously, some level of growth versus the broader market is probably desirable, just not 20%, 25%, 30% where the industry was. So how do you think about that reinvestment rate? Is there a cap on your spending? Is there a cap on your growth rate? I know you're not there yet because you've survived the second quarter, more than survived the second quarter, but just philosophically, when you think about the long term, what are the parameters that are feeding into your thought process about what you want to offer to the market?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Right. For most of my career, we would reinvest all our cash flow and then show our success by how much we could grow our production. That's how this industry worked for a long time. Well, that's not how it's going to work in the future. And so I think ph
componenttext:
Right. For most of my career, we would reinvest all our cash flow and then show our success by how much we could grow our production. That's how this industry worked for a long time. Well, that's not how it's going to work in the future. And so I think philosophically staying focused on the efficiency of the business, driving down cost, what does it cost to add a barrel of production, what are your returns, those types of things, I think it's probably going to be measured in percentages of your total cash flow that are reinvested into the business and reducing those percentages over time to be able to show continued growth. I also mentioned that I thought our industry as a whole needed to be more aware of price signals and what was going on in the market. 
So as we entered this cycle, no one really thought that U.S. shales could grow as much as they did, add as much production, and that threw everything out of balance at a really bad time. And so I think as consolidation takes place and the major producers get their shops in order, I think everybody is going to have to be more aware of supply and demand fundamentals in the world. And yes, I think what you're talking about is lower growth required bigger cash flow distributions, less percentage of your total cash flow reinvested into the business, more efficient machines.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, Tim, you've led the market early from 2 years ago when you started talking about the Shale 2.0 business model. So it's great to hear. And again, congrats on sticking with it through this tough time.
componenttext: Well, Tim, you've led the market early from 2 years ago when you started talking about the Shale 2.0 business model. So it's great to hear. And again, congrats on sticking with it through this tough time.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Tim, we've had a lot of talk about consolidation and rationalization and so forth. And it seems, obviously, one of the reasons for the industry's capital and efficiency is because creditors continue to restructure losing business instead of just selling a
componenttext: Tim, we've had a lot of talk about consolidation and rationalization and so forth. And it seems, obviously, one of the reasons for the industry's capital and efficiency is because creditors continue to restructure losing business instead of just selling assets. I'm just wondering what your sense was, if any. There are some of the folks behind the scenes providing this capital to the industry are losing patients with the effort?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I just -- yes, I commented that there wasn't any capital available to our industry. Private equity seems to be closed, public equities closed, the debt markets are tougher. So I think that is a key signal. And I think there will not be as much
componenttext: Yes. Well, I just -- yes, I commented that there wasn't any capital available to our industry. Private equity seems to be closed, public equities closed, the debt markets are tougher. So I think that is a key signal. And I think there will not be as much sloppiness in the future as there has been in the past.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for my follow-up, if you can comment. Shouldn't new administration be unconstructive on the federal leases with conscious capital allocation between the Midland and the Delaware remain roughly similar to the present or might change on that basis
componenttext: Okay. And for my follow-up, if you can comment. Shouldn't new administration be unconstructive on the federal leases with conscious capital allocation between the Midland and the Delaware remain roughly similar to the present or might change on that basis?

componenttextpreview: I don't have the -- I'll probably kick it to Will, but we have a big position in New Mexico, in state land and private land also, and also a big position in the Delaware and Texas. So we think we could keep our balance between those 2 basins.
componenttext: I don't have the -- I'll probably kick it to Will, but we have a big position in New Mexico, in state land and private land also, and also a big position in the Delaware and Texas. So we think we could keep our balance between those 2 basins.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably a good approximation. Like I mentioned in my comments, I mean, I think one of the challenges in talking about it is you don't exactly know what a new administration might do. And so you'd have to kind of take the facts as they come
componenttext: I think that's probably a good approximation. Like I mentioned in my comments, I mean, I think one of the challenges in talking about it is you don't exactly know what a new administration might do. And so you'd have to kind of take the facts as they come to you.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: One question as you think about the expansion of the Solaris Water joint venture. Can you talk about your capital commitment? And then the overall impacts on Concho's financials as that flows forward?
componenttext: One question as you think about the expansion of the Solaris Water joint venture. Can you talk about your capital commitment? And then the overall impacts on Concho's financials as that flows forward?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes. I mean a lot of the commentary we gave around the transaction we did with them in Eddy County, a couple of quarters ago, would apply to this conversation around what we've done now with them, expanding into Lea County. The benefits to us are on
componenttext:
Sure. Yes. I mean a lot of the commentary we gave around the transaction we did with them in Eddy County, a couple of quarters ago, would apply to this conversation around what we've done now with them, expanding into Lea County. The benefits to us are on both the capital side and that this entity will be spending capital dollars to build out water infrastructure as opposed to ourselves. It will also help on the lease operating expense side and help us continue to drive down to the extent we're trucking any water. This will get -- should get all of our water on the pipe over time. 
And then one of the kind of longer term, but it's still a very important goal is to increase our percentage of recycled water use. And our opinion is that you're going to need to have big third-party infrastructure to handle big bonds of water and move it around the basin where it's needed as opposed to the older model where individual companies kind of built it themselves and utilized it at pretty low rates. And so those are kind of the drivers for it. I think an important also piece of it is that the existing equity owners agreed to increase their capital commitment to the entity. So I think it sits in a very good position and helps take the burden off of us from a capital standpoint.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum with Cowen.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum with Cowen.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: If I could ask, I guess, just following up on David's question. Lea County has been one of your more active areas. How quickly should we see this impact to well cost and LOE? And then my follow-up to that would just be, I think you commented, obviously, t
componenttext: If I could ask, I guess, just following up on David's question. Lea County has been one of your more active areas. How quickly should we see this impact to well cost and LOE? And then my follow-up to that would just be, I think you commented, obviously, that you're below your target for footage cost this year, leading edge. Could you give us some parameters around where you're at? So I guess if we had annualized that, it sounds like you'd be down similarly in that sort of mid-single digits going into next year?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the water question, I mean, I think it's noteworthy that a big portion of the improvement on both the capital and LOE sides have been some of the things we're doing around water, both from a sourcing and disposal standpoint. So a fair amount of t
componenttext: Sure. On the water question, I mean, I think it's noteworthy that a big portion of the improvement on both the capital and LOE sides have been some of the things we're doing around water, both from a sourcing and disposal standpoint. So a fair amount of that was already baked into getting to where we are today. We do expect to see incremental benefit, but it will probably be modest from where we are with that transaction. As to your kind of broader question on drill completing the equip costs and where they go in the future, the number we're talking about is a annual program-wide number. It's not aspirational. It's kind of the whole program, short laterals, long laterals, et cetera. And so I do think we'll continue to trend that down over the course of the year and into next year, but time will tell in terms of where that goes. And I think it will also be driven by what's happening from an activity level in the Permian in the back half of this year.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Do you suspect that there are going to be some inflationary pressures on the service cost side? I mean if everyone is more or less holding maintenance mode similar to you all, do you think that there's still pockets where you're going to see some pricing
componenttext: Do you suspect that there are going to be some inflationary pressures on the service cost side? I mean if everyone is more or less holding maintenance mode similar to you all, do you think that there's still pockets where you're going to see some pricing pressure?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean to a point Jack made earlier, our capital strategy has been to try to slow down and level out over the course of this year, our production base. It seems like some of our peers have a bit more of a dramatic V where they have cut activity. And
componenttext: Yes. I mean to a point Jack made earlier, our capital strategy has been to try to slow down and level out over the course of this year, our production base. It seems like some of our peers have a bit more of a dramatic V where they have cut activity. And so it seems like some of them -- this earnings season will be pretty helpful in terms of getting some insight into how they are thinking about it. But I do think we will see some modest level of activity from peers come back in the back half of this year and then try and kind of level out maybe a deeper V if production decreases.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Tim, Jack and Will, and your whole crew there. You guys have gone through a whole lot of -- recovered a lot of ground here, but I just wanted to ask one other question, kind of, along the same lines, but from a different angle. If you guys,
componenttext: Good morning, Tim, Jack and Will, and your whole crew there. You guys have gone through a whole lot of -- recovered a lot of ground here, but I just wanted to ask one other question, kind of, along the same lines, but from a different angle. If you guys, 6 months from now, were able to swap another big chunk of your production in the high 40s on WTI kind of along the lines of those swatch you already have in place, would that be sufficient for you guys to want to add to that 8 rig and 4 rig or 4 completion crew pace?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charles. This is Jack. Just on the hedging piece, first off, we're pretty mechanical about the way we go about that. And so we won't be waiting for any particular price to add hedges. We will continue quarterly to look at that and kind of plan aro
componenttext: Thanks, Charles. This is Jack. Just on the hedging piece, first off, we're pretty mechanical about the way we go about that. And so we won't be waiting for any particular price to add hedges. We will continue quarterly to look at that and kind of plan around what the future looks like. But I think, as Tim and really all of us have alluded to here on the reinvestment, it's -- we need to be more mindful of all the things going on in the world and the signals that we're getting. And right now, adding a lot of production and activity doesn't seem to be the signal.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question from the line of Gail Nicholson with Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question from the line of Gail Nicholson with Stephens.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: When you guys look at your current cycle time improvements that you achieved over the last 12 months, what do you think is the most impressive achievement?
componenttext: When you guys look at your current cycle time improvements that you achieved over the last 12 months, what do you think is the most impressive achievement?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of them. And really, I think you have to say that getting to where we are today is the aggregation of a lot of small gains as opposed to any one individual piece. So I'm a little challenged to pick one, other than just to say, I think the te
componenttext: There's a lot of them. And really, I think you have to say that getting to where we are today is the aggregation of a lot of small gains as opposed to any one individual piece. So I'm a little challenged to pick one, other than just to say, I think the teams are focused on the right things and are having good success at it.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: When you look at the potential incremental cycle time improvements, do you think that there's one area that there's more improvement that could be achieved?
componenttext: When you look at the potential incremental cycle time improvements, do you think that there's one area that there's more improvement that could be achieved?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: No. I think probably one of the big challenges or focuses will be, if activity in the basin does increase, holding the gains, holding the quality crews and rigs that we've got, and so that probably would be a big point of focus if you see some increased a
componenttext: No. I think probably one of the big challenges or focuses will be, if activity in the basin does increase, holding the gains, holding the quality crews and rigs that we've got, and so that probably would be a big point of focus if you see some increased activity in the back half of the year.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nitin Kumar with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nitin Kumar with Wells Fargo.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: A lot of my questions have been asked already, but one topic that I guess, hasn't been addressed is the cost, the LOE this quarter was quite low sequentially. I think you've deferred some workovers and maintenance activity. How should we think about LOE?
componenttext: A lot of my questions have been asked already, but one topic that I guess, hasn't been addressed is the cost, the LOE this quarter was quite low sequentially. I think you've deferred some workovers and maintenance activity. How should we think about LOE? I think your guidance for the rest of the year bakes that in, but how should we think about it long term? Is the $4.50-or-so number for LOE an achievable target in 2021? Or should we stick with somewhere between $5 to $5.50?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Nitin, it's Will. We're at kind of $5.50 in the first quarter and we were around at the $4.50 in the second quarter. And if you try and look and see what drove that pretty dramatic improvement, it's a combination of things, including just kind of process
componenttext: Nitin, it's Will. We're at kind of $5.50 in the first quarter and we were around at the $4.50 in the second quarter. And if you try and look and see what drove that pretty dramatic improvement, it's a combination of things, including just kind of process improvement, some of these things we're doing around water, around power generation and getting off of generators and ESPs and other things we're doing on artificial lift. So those gains should be sustainable, and that's probably about half of the improvement. The other half, as you referenced, kind of came from an unnatural, basically stopping our workover program in conjunction with trying to manage through the curtailment period there in the second quarter, and so that piece is not sustainable. So I think kind of half of that gain is and half is not. If that helps you dial it in.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nicholas Pope with Seaport Global.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nicholas Pope with Seaport Global.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the emissions and ESG slide that you provided. I'm just curious, you kind of highlighted that you brought flaring down to 1% on the year. And I hope you could talk just real quick about kind of how you all have been achieving that redu
componenttext: I had a question on the emissions and ESG slide that you provided. I'm just curious, you kind of highlighted that you brought flaring down to 1% on the year. And I hope you could talk just real quick about kind of how you all have been achieving that reduction? I just want to know how much is based on kind of lower activity versus kind of capturing and processing the gas, reinjecting the gas. Where is the gas going that I guess was being flared? And how sustainable do you all think that 1% kind of number is and kind of pushing that lower? Because it's a great -- I mean, it's a great trend that you guys have been on with that machine side of things.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Nick, it's Will. I'm going to take a shot at that. That has been a major focal point in our company here for a couple of years. And it really -- you got to give the operational team and especially the guys in the field a lot of credit for doing that. A bi
componenttext: Nick, it's Will. I'm going to take a shot at that. That has been a major focal point in our company here for a couple of years. And it really -- you got to give the operational team and especially the guys in the field a lot of credit for doing that. A big key is not having any flaring around new well hookups. And so there's been great coordination with our midstream partners making sure that we have the gas pipe there when you're ready to go on the production side. And also, frankly, in getting down to the numbers we're in, being unwilling to produce new oil unless you have that gas oil gathering. And so that has barrel impact from a production standpoint. And we, as an organization, have decided that, that's worth it to achieve the goals around flaring. The rest of it, what's left, is really around the typical plant upsets and things that happen in the field on a daily basis, and you definitely had a more benign operating environment here in the second quarter just as activity was coming off, typically.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Got it. And do you think that's sustainable as activity in the basin? And as your own activity ramps back up, do you think the numbers where you're at right now are sustainable longer term on that?
componenttext: Got it. And do you think that's sustainable as activity in the basin? And as your own activity ramps back up, do you think the numbers where you're at right now are sustainable longer term on that?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Our goal is to keep grinding it lower.
componenttext: Our goal is to keep grinding it lower.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020

componenttext: At this time, I would like to turn the call back over to management.

componenttext: Okay. Thank you for being interested in our company dialing in. I know this is the beginning of a busy earnings season. Once again, I'm very proud of the performance of the company in the second quarter and look forward to talking to you in the next quarter. Thank you very much.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2020 Concho Resources Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please be advised that today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I would
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2020 Concho Resources Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please be advised that today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to hand the conference over to Ms. Megan Hays, Vice President of Investor Relations and Public Affairs. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter conference call. As a reminder, during today's conference call, we will provide forward-looking statements based on current expectations. I'll call your attention to the forward-look
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter conference call. As a reminder, during today's conference call, we will provide forward-looking statements based on current expectations. I'll call your attention to the forward-looking statements and other disclaimers that are provided in the earnings release and presentation. Our comments today may also reference non-GAAP financial metrics and reconciliations for those metrics can be found in our earnings release. You can find the earnings release and presentation on the Investor Relations page of the Concho website. 
Joining me on the call today are Tim Leach, Concho's Chairman and CEO; along with President, Jack Harper; Chief Operating Officer, Will Giraud. 
Tim is going to begin, followed by Jack, who will give you a review of our financial results and outlook. Following their prepared remarks, we will be happy to take your questions. Please limit yourself to 1 question and 1 follow-up. With that, I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Megan. Good morning. The second quarter tested the strength of the industry, and I'm confident we're even stronger company after the recent challenges. Not many companies are going to come out of this stronger, but I believe that we're one of them
componenttext:
Thanks, Megan. Good morning. The second quarter tested the strength of the industry, and I'm confident we're even stronger company after the recent challenges. Not many companies are going to come out of this stronger, but I believe that we're one of them. 
As I think about the first half of this year, we've made real progress on several priorities that will position us for the future: maximizing our cash flow by adjusting our spend rate, production and cost structure; increasing the strength of our balance sheet; continuing to return capital to shareholders through our dividend; and managing the oil price volatility with capital discipline, while also preserving our operational capacity. 
The last several months have been more volatile than anything we've ever seen. Oil ended the quarter up 92%, the largest move in the quarter in 30 years. But what a ride. Oil prices dropped to negative $38 then rebounded to positive $40 as the U.S. and OPEC+ cut production. Against a volatile backdrop and historically weak price realizations, Concho delivered strong operational and financial performance in the second quarter. Our results reflect the strength of our portfolio and our team. We delivered strong cash flows and lower cost while we cut our activity.
Moving forward, we're maintaining the same level of focus that helped us navigate the first half of the year. In short, we'll continue to remain flexible. And as we look past 2020, we will be patient for sustained higher prices before increasing spending.
Today, there are 125 rigs running in the Permian. A year ago, there were 440 and frac spreads have declined even more dramatically. This reduction in activity is starting to show up as declining Permian production. In addition, fuel declines are setting in, capital continues to be scarce and we're seeing the effects of a shrinking industry. We believe the future of our industry requires better-capitalized companies, more capital discipline, less leverage and being more aware of market signals for growth. Before the pandemic, we outlined a clear vision for the evolution of our business, delivering both sustainable cash flow growth, production growth and increasing returns to shareholders. While there's more uncertainty than usual around the macroeconomic environment, this plan remains unchanged. And the principles that form our strategy, people, assets, returns and financial strength, will guide us along the way. 
Operating responsibly is key to the evolution of the business model as well. We believe that operating responsibly and delivering good financial performance are not mutually exclusive. Our flaring performance in 2020 is trending toward 1% of gross operated gas volumes as compared to 1.8% in 2019. In August, we'll publish our first sustainability report. We look forward to engaging with you on these important topics.
We continue to work through the pandemic and the impact that it's having on our communities and workforce. I want to acknowledge the hard work of our employees. They continue to perform well in a tough environment. This was a great quarter, and I'm proud of our performance. 
Before I turn the call over to Jack, I want to summarize a few things that I hope you will come away with. First, we're successfully managing this cycle without losing focus on the long-term value and operational capacity of the company. Also, we're improving our operational performance, which is lowering our cost structure. Next, we're continuing to reduce our net debt. And finally, we will be patient on the recovery, prioritizing free cash flow and reinforcing our machine. 
With that, let me turn it over to Jack.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. Our results for the second quarter not only continue our trend of solid financial and operating performance, they also demonstrate that we are controlling what we can. And by doing so, we are well positioned to become a more profitable com
componenttext:
Thank you, Tim. Our results for the second quarter not only continue our trend of solid financial and operating performance, they also demonstrate that we are controlling what we can. And by doing so, we are well positioned to become a more profitable company. Last quarter, we outlined the steps that we're taking to align our business with the current environment. Those steps include reducing our capital program, improving our cost structure and reinforcing our balance sheet.
Regarding our capital program. CapEx in the second quarter totaled $312 million, 44% lower than the first quarter this year. The step down in the quarter reflects less overall activity as well as continued improvement in well costs. For the second time this year, we are reducing our well cost guidance due to better operational efficiencies and a lower service cost environment. We expect the cost to drill, complete and equip a well to average less than $800 per foot or more than 30% lower than the cost to do that work last year. 
With respect to our cost structure. Controllable costs, which includes lease operating, cash G&A and interest expense totaled $7.49 per unit, down 20% from 2019. We are managing all aspects of our cost structure. Examples include the logical items like well maintenance, workovers, water handling and optimizing artificial lift. We also made the difficult decision to implement a voluntary separation program. These combined efforts are expected to result in more than $135 million in reduced operating and G&A costs, up from our prior target of $100 million. Quickly adjusting our capital program and managing our costs lower, combined with our hedge position drove strong cash flow generation. Operating cash flow before working capital was $550 million, which resulted in $238 million of free cash flow, which brings me to reinforcing our balance sheet. 
Our cash position nearly doubled to $320 million, and at the end of the second quarter, our net debt was $3.6 billion, down from $4.3 billion a year ago, despite commodity price volatility. And although we have one of the better balance sheets in the industry, we plan to direct the $375 million to $450 million of free cash flow anticipated in the back half of the year to our balance sheet, making quick progress towards our goal to reduce net debt by another $600 million. 
Oil volumes for the second quarter averaged 200,000 barrels per day, and we remain on track with our full year guide of approximately 197,000 barrels per day and $1.6 billion in capital spending. We've built a leading position in one of the best resource basins in the world. Our portfolio quality, depth and durability are nearly unmatched. Importantly, we have a good mix of investment opportunities across federal state and private lands. This mix allows us to redirect capital without degrading the returns or the capital efficiency of our drilling program. And as Tim discussed, we are working to minimize our emissions as well. 
I'm confident that our operating principles and performance regardless of the environment we're in. Without question, this has been a challenging year thus far, testing every company. To meet the challenge, we're maintaining our approach to capital discipline and prioritizing free cash flow. I believe that our second quarter results show that the steps we are taking are enabling us to build a better company, driven by more efficient capital investment and cost control.
With that, let me turn the call over to the operator for Q&A.

And I'm just hoping you all could maybe kind of elaborate on kind of how you all went through sort of the thought process on the trade-off of whether you don't complete the 20 additional wells or you just reduced the full year CapEx budget?

componenttext: Sure, John, it's Jack. As we described last quarter, we're trying to have that balance between prudently investing our capital and maintaining our production base as we end the year. And we feel like this strikes that balance of maintaining a stable production base but also building a little bit of momentum as we start the budget season for '21.

componenttext: And then when we look at the continued progress you all have made on reducing the well cost now that's a less than $800 a foot versus the $850. Can you elaborate a little bit more on sort of just ballpark of that drop, how much is just due to efficiency gains versus service pricing and then sort of what areas, if any, if you think there's still room to kind of drive those efficiencies more?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: John, it's Will. Yes, I think if you just kind of looked at the improvement, roughly half of it is related to efficiency gains and another half is kind of more just service cost pricing coming down. And I think there's probably still some work to be done
componenttext: John, it's Will. Yes, I think if you just kind of looked at the improvement, roughly half of it is related to efficiency gains and another half is kind of more just service cost pricing coming down. And I think there's probably still some work to be done on both of those sides. I think the team has done a really good job continuing to improve cycle times. I think there's more work to do there as well. On the service cost side, it will depend on what activity levels look like, here, in the Permian, in the back half of the year.

componenttext: I wanted to follow up on your debt reduction objective to get debt down to $3.0 billion, a $600 million reduction. What are your thoughts, and how philosophically would achieving that goal then impact subsequent actions? When you get to $3 billion, then what happens next? Is that where you would more quickly increase returns to shareholders? Would you just continue to have an even lower debt reduction goal? Would there be capital to allocate to production growth, which you said earlier, with an longer-term -- a longer-term objective. Can you talk a little bit more about that?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020

componenttext: Yes. We've talked about that in the past, too, that we felt like a stronger balance sheet in this kind of environment was kind of a top priority. So I think getting to that goal, getting to that goal quickly, enables you to then look at all the other options on how to return capital to shareholders. So I think that is the logical next step.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Great. And is there any frameworks that you're considering either in terms of more of a variable dividend, dividend versus share repurchase, and then percent of capital allocated to growth projects versus give it to shareholders?
componenttext: Great. And is there any frameworks that you're considering either in terms of more of a variable dividend, dividend versus share repurchase, and then percent of capital allocated to growth projects versus give it to shareholders?

componenttext: No, I mean we've talked about all those. The variable dividend is getting a lot of traction right now. But I would tell you, I'm just -- the main message from this quarter is, I'm so happy that we have a viable, strong business at this new pricing level. That's the main message. And that we can very quickly get by producing more free cash flow and running our business, we can get this thing -- balance sheet position where we think it's appropriate for any scenario in the future, and that gives us all kind of optionality, especially if we have a return to pricing like we've had in the past.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my last one is on well performance and really a little bit of a 2-parter. The first is, can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing from the well performance to date, particularly as it relates to the spacing? And how some of t
componenttext: Great. And then my last one is on well performance and really a little bit of a 2-parter. The first is, can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing from the well performance to date, particularly as it relates to the spacing? And how some of those wells are performing, maybe not necessarily in their first 30 or 60 or 90 days but thereafter? And then also, can you talk about the base decline rate? And if there's anything beyond -- if there's anything you're doing to manage -- to best manage that?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure. Brian, it's Will. On the performance side, I mean, the quarterly production was right kind of in line with what we expected. The well performance, I would characterize the same. If you're asking about kind of the latest batch of projects that are at
componenttext: Sure. Brian, it's Will. On the performance side, I mean, the quarterly production was right kind of in line with what we expected. The well performance, I would characterize the same. If you're asking about kind of the latest batch of projects that are at a spacing density less than some of the tests we did in 2019, those -- it's worth noting they're still relatively early in their life, but they look in line with what we would expect. So that all feels pretty good. As it relates to the base decline, I'd still -- I think we would still talk about that low 40s for this first year decline, but finding a way to continue to moderate that. I do think that as we go at a slower pace, you will see that moderate maybe a little faster than we were expecting in previous conversations, but that's probably to come later.

componenttext: Perhaps for you, Jack. With regard to your 2020 outlook, I certainly appreciate the challenges of providing quarterly guidance in the current environment. With the activity you've outlined, would it be safe to assume you could exit the year about where you are now? And the reason I asked is that I seem to recall on your Q1 commentary, the flattish profile for the balance of the year, that was your comments back then.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derrick. Yes. If anything, since our last call and our last conversation, my confidence has increased in our business. And as for the second half oil production, I do still expect for it to stabilize in that 190 to 200 a day range. But we left our
componenttext:
Thanks, Derrick. Yes. If anything, since our last call and our last conversation, my confidence has increased in our business. And as for the second half oil production, I do still expect for it to stabilize in that 190 to 200 a day range. But we left our annual guidance unchanged for a couple of reasons. First off, mid-90s on oil in the back half of the year, only positively impacts that annual number by about 1%. And additionally, exit-to-exit rate basis, we see our production holding up well and better than most. 
And secondly, we described in the last quarter, our focus on free cash flow generation. And our improved cost structure, along with a stable production base have us ahead of plan in that regard. And then lastly, I guess I'd say the style and cadence of our program in the back half of the year will allow us to enter next year with maximum flexibility, a stable production base and a strong financial position. I think many of our peers will struggle to achieve that.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Great. And then perhaps for you, Will, on the follow-up question. And I'd like to really circle back to the topic that I raised last quarter and frame it slightly differently, that is, what a lower for longer price environment where the investor asked is
componenttext: Great. And then perhaps for you, Will, on the follow-up question. And I'd like to really circle back to the topic that I raised last quarter and frame it slightly differently, that is, what a lower for longer price environment where the investor asked is flattish growth and return of capital. Would that environment change your view on optimal spacing? And I acknowledge in asking this question that you're spacing is conservative relative to industry based on the operational adjustments you made in the second half of last year. But is there an opportunity to get greater returns with wider spacing?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean we've definitely moved to a wider spacing here in 2020. I don't necessarily think that you'd see us adjust to something wider than that, if that's kind of what you're asking, if I'm understanding the question right. I do think given the volati
componenttext: Yes. I mean we've definitely moved to a wider spacing here in 2020. I don't necessarily think that you'd see us adjust to something wider than that, if that's kind of what you're asking, if I'm understanding the question right. I do think given the volatility we see in the commodity and a whole host of other factors, including willing to run a relatively steady program, I think we're very comfortable with the cadence of our business right now and also the spacing patterns and targets we're going after.

componenttextpreview: I guess the story of the quarter was clearly the free cash flow and the lower CapEx. I was wondering if you could help us think about maybe the second half trajectory of CapEx and perhaps some of the drivers of the lower CapEx in 2Q.
componenttext: I guess the story of the quarter was clearly the free cash flow and the lower CapEx. I was wondering if you could help us think about maybe the second half trajectory of CapEx and perhaps some of the drivers of the lower CapEx in 2Q.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure, Arun, it's Will. Yes, the drivers on the CapEx improvement so far, as Jack mentioned, was a couple of things. It was activity obviously slowing down over the course of the year, but then also pretty impressive improvement in just our cost structure
componenttext: Sure, Arun, it's Will. Yes, the drivers on the CapEx improvement so far, as Jack mentioned, was a couple of things. It was activity obviously slowing down over the course of the year, but then also pretty impressive improvement in just our cost structure on the drill of completing the quip side. As it relates to the back half of the year, there's a couple of things happening there. First, our activity in the second half has a little bit more activity on higher working interest properties, including 5 rigs that are currently on the Mabee Ranch, where we've got 100% working interest. Second, we saw a very low amount of nonoperated capital in 2Q. And so I think our expectation is, we'll still see that non-op activity come to see us in the back half of the year. And so that was kind of another toggle on the capital.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020

componenttext: Great. And well, how does this influence your views kind of sustaining CapEx on a go-forward basis? I mean I think you guys have publicly talked about something now and, call it, in the $1.4 billion range. Please just stop me if I'm incorrect with that view and just thoughts on how that could translate in terms of 2021 sustaining CapEx?

componenttextpreview: Yes. We've talked a lot about kind of that run rate. We're going to be at here in the back half of the year, that $350 million a quarter being a good proxy for maintenance capital. I think this quarter shows that really what we're focused on right now is
componenttext: Yes. We've talked a lot about kind of that run rate. We're going to be at here in the back half of the year, that $350 million a quarter being a good proxy for maintenance capital. I think this quarter shows that really what we're focused on right now is controlling the things we can control and grinding on costs, whether they are capital costs or lease expense costs or G&A cost. And so we're going to keep working on that number. But for now, I think that's a good number to have.

componenttext: Sure. Scott, it's Will. I think it's 8 and 4 right now; 8 rigs, 4 completion crews, and that's probably a good number. We tried to talk more in terms of capital than activity, just because, as I mentioned, there can be a little bit of noise as we bounce around between different working interests in different projects. But that is a good just kind of a straw man for activity.

componenttext: Got it. Appreciate that. And then, Tim, you had mentioned that, obviously, companies that are better capitalized are in a better position, especially in this volatile oil market that we're in. Can you guys give us your 10,000-foot view on M&A going forward here, considering what's occurred and how does Concho play into that?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, we're really focused on running our business efficiently. And I do think -- I mean, we've seen consolidations happen in our industry. I think individual deals are just that, they are individual deals if they are all different. So I don't think you c
componenttext: Well, we're really focused on running our business efficiently. And I do think -- I mean, we've seen consolidations happen in our industry. I think individual deals are just that, they are individual deals if they are all different. So I don't think you can characterize consolidation by any one deal or perhaps the last deal that just happened. But I do think the industry, in general, is going to have to get more efficient. And to get more efficient than these companies and the industries going to have to be better capitalized and be able to run at lower cost with less debt. And so I think we'll see that happen. I'm not sure how that affects Concho. Concho is really well positioned with the property base we have and where we're located. I think we can continue to do what we do for a very long time. So we've -- I think our #1 mission right now is just to continue to create a more efficient company with what we've got.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate that. But just out of curiosity, are you -- I'm assuming you guys look at the market constantly. Have you seen anything change in that market over the last several months?
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate that. But just out of curiosity, are you -- I'm assuming you guys look at the market constantly. Have you seen anything change in that market over the last several months?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the second quarter was maybe the worst quarter we've ever had as an industry as far as the oil price movement and just -- so yes, I think that everybody was looking at their business plan, and there were very few business plans that were via
componenttext: Well, I mean, the second quarter was maybe the worst quarter we've ever had as an industry as far as the oil price movement and just -- so yes, I think that everybody was looking at their business plan, and there were very few business plans that were viable in our industry. So I think that forces the industry to reevaluate itself.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Neal Dingmann with SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Neal Dingmann with SunTrust.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: First, I guess my 2 questions is, well, based on, Tim, what you and Will said earlier. First, Will had mentioned -- talked about maintenance capital and other question, and then Tim, not a surprise, you talked about returning -- or just talked about share
componenttext: First, I guess my 2 questions is, well, based on, Tim, what you and Will said earlier. First, Will had mentioned -- talked about maintenance capital and other question, and then Tim, not a surprise, you talked about returning -- or just talked about shareholder returns. So both of my questions are on this, I'm just wondering on the -- I think it's $350 million to $375 million per quarter maintenance capital. My first question is, is that -- do you anticipate that continuing to come down even a bit more. It just seems like you guys are doing an incredible job with efficiencies, and then my second part today would be, if that does come down or, I guess, let's say, the adverse of that prices go up, it sounds like, Tim, would you just keep that the same and not grow production anymore and just take that capital and give it back to shareholders? Or I'm just wondering, again, basically around this maintenance capital. Can it get any better? And what would you do with the excess?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that and then let Tim or Jack take the second. I mean as it relates to what we've been able to do so far this year, I can't say enough positive things about our drilling and completion teams and what they have done to take adva
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that and then let Tim or Jack take the second. I mean as it relates to what we've been able to do so far this year, I can't say enough positive things about our drilling and completion teams and what they have done to take advantage of not only the lower service cost environment we're in and to have the flexible program and be able to take advantage of that. But also the efficiency gains, the cycle time, the footage per day improvement, et cetera, it's been really impressive. And I'm optimistic that given more time, the machine will continue to grind out gains. And over some measure of time, we will continue to deliver.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. Neal, I think the answer to your other question is, as I mentioned, at the very opening that we're going to be very cautious on increasing any kind of activity and require a much stronger and longer price signals from the market before we do such.
componenttext: Yes. Neal, I think the answer to your other question is, as I mentioned, at the very opening that we're going to be very cautious on increasing any kind of activity and require a much stronger and longer price signals from the market before we do such.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: So Tim, let me ask one last one. So does that mean you'd consider -- even though it is potentially would be called a variable dividend, is that something you would look at and something you'd consider from time to time throughout the year when you conside
componenttext: So Tim, let me ask one last one. So does that mean you'd consider -- even though it is potentially would be called a variable dividend, is that something you would look at and something you'd consider from time to time throughout the year when you consider shareholder return options?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not really ready to talk about the mechanic of it, but the concept of a variable dividends being talked about throughout our industry, and I think we'd be well positioned to do something like that.
componenttext: Yes. I'm not really ready to talk about the mechanic of it, but the concept of a variable dividends being talked about throughout our industry, and I think we'd be well positioned to do something like that.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Leo Mariani with KeyBanc.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on free cash flow. It certainly seems like your message was pretty clear in terms of what you'd be doing in the second half of the year with, I guess, building cash to reduce net debt. But I guess, maybe just kind o
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on free cash flow. It certainly seems like your message was pretty clear in terms of what you'd be doing in the second half of the year with, I guess, building cash to reduce net debt. But I guess, maybe just kind of going forward into next year, I wanted to get a sense of how share buybacks might play into the equation here. Wasn't a word that I heard you guys, I guess, mention of late?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Yes, Leo, this is Jack. Yes, as Tim alluded to earlier, I think we can get substantially there on our debt reduction by the end of this year with perhaps a little bit of work to do next year. But beyond that, what we've described in the past and on this c
componenttext: Yes, Leo, this is Jack. Yes, as Tim alluded to earlier, I think we can get substantially there on our debt reduction by the end of this year with perhaps a little bit of work to do next year. But beyond that, what we've described in the past and on this call is a range of opportunities between increasing dividends, share buyback or further cash build. And I think we really have to see what the circumstances look like at that point in time to determine which one is the most effective.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess just -- I know it's kind of tough to say how things play out, obviously, on the oil price side as we get into next year. But we've kind of stabilized here at roughly $40, and it sounds like the situation you guys are describing is that y
componenttext: Okay. And I guess just -- I know it's kind of tough to say how things play out, obviously, on the oil price side as we get into next year. But we've kind of stabilized here at roughly $40, and it sounds like the situation you guys are describing is that you can kind of start to stabilize your oil volumes into year-end? I mean I don't want to put words in your mouth, but it would be reasonable to assume that if we continue to muddle along at $40 next year, we should think of Concho volumes as fairly flat and activity fairly flat. And you guys talk about needing a much higher oil price to potentially grow again? Would that be closer to 45%? Just trying to get some bookends as to how this can play out.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we came into this year, we described our business plan in the $50 environment and the things we could do. And as prices have bounced around and costs have changed, clearly, what could be done at $50 can now be done at a lower price. And when we
componenttext: Sure. When we came into this year, we described our business plan in the $50 environment and the things we could do. And as prices have bounced around and costs have changed, clearly, what could be done at $50 can now be done at a lower price. And when we look out at the strip currently and what we think our business can do, it's a viable business that can achieve a lot of the same objectives we came into the year talking about.

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just lastly on the shut-ins. Are all those back online at this point? And any -- if not, can you quantify what's still off-line?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just lastly on the shut-ins. Are all those back online at this point? And any -- if not, can you quantify what's still off-line?

headline: Concho Resources Inc., Q2 2020 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2020
